evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the preliminary history of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history that contradicts or defeats the claim of communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history, such as miscommunication and lack of coordination.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical preliminary timeframe of 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The environmental or marking deficiency in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical preliminary timeframe of 12-25 is robust against potential defeaters or contradictory evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the historical preliminary data of 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure explanation withstands potential defeaters and remains the most plausible cause for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 in hist_t0_prelim.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in hist_t0_prelim.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical preliminary data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical preliminary context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical preliminary dataset.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented in the preliminary history of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25.

assumptions: The documented communications in H1-H3 reflect the overall communication status among crew.
The continued movement beyond TRP in H4 implies a coordination or communication failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation without communication issues, or mechanical faults causing the incident, the conclusion would change.
If the communication was documented as effective and no breakdown occurred, the claim would be contradicted.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, supporting the presence of communication; however, H4 indicates a failure to stop at the TRP, consistent with a coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the failure to stop was due to communication breakdown or procedural deviation

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.

defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction such as fault codes, bench checks, or repeated malfunctions would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe communication and operator actions during pushback, with no direct indication of mechanical/control failure; the aircraft overrunning the TRP suggests possible procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure, favoring communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary history, such as miscommunication and lack of coordination.

assumptions: The observed behaviors of the tug operators and crew communication reflect coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation alone.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without miscommunication or lack of coordination, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators with some miscoordination (H2, H3) and the aircraft moving beyond the TRP (H4), supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the pushback procedural deviation or environment factors contributed more to the event.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical preliminary timeframe of 12-25.

assumptions: The aircraft moving beyond the TRP despite the marking implies the marking was deficient or not adequately observable.
No other causes such as procedural deviation or mechanical failure are indicated in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the markings were clear and visible but the pushback was improperly executed, this would favor procedural deviation instead.
If mechanical faults or communication breakdowns were documented causing the event, the environmental deficiency claim would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly describes the aircraft moving beyond the TRP ground markings and hitting a barrier, indicating the presence and observability of an environmental or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit description of marking visibility or adequacy; assumption that the continued movement beyond TRP implies marking deficiency.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical preliminary data.

defeaters: If documentation or explicit reference to procedural deviation in the historical preliminary data is provided, this would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence explicitly documents or confirms availability of procedural deviation in the historical preliminary data for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the historical preliminary data of 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or if there were physical marking/location issues documented.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and hit a barrier, indicating the environmental or marking deficiency does not align with key features, favoring procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

No hidden communication breakdown occurred beyond what is described
defeaters: If evidence showed communication failures or misunderstandings between crew or headset operator that caused the deviation
If mechanical faults or environmental factors were documented as primary causes

defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, or if mechanical control failure was confirmed, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.

defeaters: If evidence showed equipment faults or bench checks indicating control malfunction
If communication breakdown or environmental deficiencies were documented affecting equipment readiness

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows the tug and crew were operational and actively controlling the pushback, with no indication of equipment malfunction, supporting that pushback equipment was operational and ready for use.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement of equipment status; inference based on operational activity and absence of fault evidence

node.statement: Pushback crew was present and available at the scheduled time

assumptions: Presence of crew during pushback implies availability at scheduled time
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew was absent or unavailable at the scheduled time
If mechanical failure or communication breakdown was documented as cause instead

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, and H3 directly indicate that the pushback crew (instructor and trainee) were present and available at the scheduled time, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct timestamps or explicit scheduled time confirmation; assumption that presence during pushback implies availability at scheduled time.

node.statement: Communication systems between cockpit and pushback crew were functional

assumptions: Presence of communication implies functionality; no reported communication failures.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication failures or breakdowns between cockpit and pushback crew.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 indicate that communication systems between cockpit and pushback crew were functional, supporting the claim and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states communication was flawless; possible minor issues not documented.

node.statement: Mechanical control components are capable of moving as intended without restriction

defeaters: If direct mechanical fault codes or bench checks confirm mechanical control failure
If physical marking/location evidence clearly indicates environmental or procedural issues rather than mechanical failure

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the intended stop point despite engine at idle, indicating mechanical control components did not move as intended without restriction, contradicting the claim. Communication evidence (H1-H3) favors communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present and installed in the aircraft

assumptions: Physical movement of the aircraft beyond the TRP implies mechanical control components were present and functional to some extent
No evidence indicates mechanical components were missing or uninstalled
defeaters: If evidence showed the mechanical components were missing or uninstalled
If the aircraft did not physically move beyond the TRP
If communication or procedural errors fully explained the event without mechanical involvement

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft's nosewheel physically moved beyond the expected stop point, indicating mechanical control components were present and installed, supporting the claim. This also favors mechanical control failure over communication or procedural deviations per discriminators.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether mechanical control failure or other factors caused the event

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were not physically present or accessible during the event.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, and H3 directly describe crew members physically present and accessible during the event, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: Relevant environmental data (e.g., weather reports, NOTAMs) were available to the flight crew prior to the incident

defeaters: If evidence of weather reports, NOTAMs, or other environmental data available to the flight crew prior to the incident is found, this would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates that relevant environmental data such as weather reports or NOTAMs were available to the flight crew prior to the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

defeaters: If documentation or explicit reference to procedural deviation in the historical preliminary data is provided, this would change the assessment.
availability.reasoning_summary: No evidence explicitly documents or confirms availability of procedural deviation in the historical preliminary data for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings were visible and adequate as no evidence suggests otherwise.
No mechanical faults were detected or reported during the pushback.
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, or if mechanical control failure was confirmed, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows effective communication and procedural actions by the crew and tug operators, while H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP despite these actions, indicating a procedural deviation rather than environmental or mechanical causes, supporting defeater resistance.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence excludes all environmental or mechanical factors definitively; some ambiguity remains.

assumptions: The described behaviors and events represent typical procedural deviations in this context
No hidden communication breakdown occurred beyond what is described
defeaters: If evidence showed communication failures or misunderstandings between crew or headset operator that caused the deviation
If mechanical faults or environmental factors were documented as primary causes
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) describes the procedural actions and decisions during pushback, including the trainee stopping and instructor taking over, and the aircraft moving beyond the TRP, consistent with procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown, supporting the claim.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: No explicit comparison to other root causes in evidence; ambiguity remains without direct negation of alternatives.

assumptions: The documented communications in H1-H3 reflect the overall communication status among crew.
The continued movement beyond TRP in H4 implies a coordination or communication failure.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation without communication issues, or mechanical faults causing the incident, the conclusion would change.
If the communication was documented as effective and no breakdown occurred, the claim would be contradicted.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, supporting the presence of communication; however, H4 indicates a failure to stop at the TRP, consistent with a coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure, supporting the claim.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the failure to stop was due to communication breakdown or procedural deviation

defeaters: If evidence showed miscommunication or lack of coordination among crew or tug operators during pushback
If headset or interphone communication was disrupted or ignored
If crew failed to respond to cues or alerts from tug operators
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows ongoing communication and coordination efforts among crew and tug operators, with no indication of communication breakdown; the aircraft's movement beyond the TRP despite these efforts supports the claim that no communication/coordination breakdown is evident.

assumptions: The observed behaviors of the tug operators and crew communication reflect coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation alone.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without miscommunication or lack of coordination, or if mechanical failure was confirmed as primary cause.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators with some miscoordination (H2, H3) and the aircraft moving beyond the TRP (H4), supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the pushback procedural deviation or environment factors contributed more to the event.

assumptions: The aircraft moving beyond the TRP despite the marking implies the marking was deficient or not adequately observable.
No other causes such as procedural deviation or mechanical failure are indicated in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed the markings were clear and visible but the pushback was improperly executed, this would favor procedural deviation instead.
If mechanical faults or communication breakdowns were documented causing the event, the environmental deficiency claim would be weakened.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly describes the aircraft moving beyond the TRP ground markings and hitting a barrier, indicating the presence and observability of an environmental or marking deficiency.
availability.uncertainty_source: No explicit description of marking visibility or adequacy; assumption that the continued movement beyond TRP implies marking deficiency.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear marking inadequacy or poor visibility causing the incident, the environmental deficiency claim would be stronger.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the marked release point and hit a barrier, indicating a failure not robust against defeaters, favoring procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, or if there were physical marking/location issues documented.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and hit a barrier, indicating the environmental or marking deficiency does not align with key features, favoring procedural deviation over marking deficiency.

defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction such as fault codes, bench checks, or repeated malfunctions would change the assessment.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe communication and operator actions during pushback, with no direct indication of mechanical/control failure; the aircraft overrunning the TRP suggests possible procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure, favoring communication breakdown over mechanical failure.

assumptions: No hidden mechanical faults were present beyond the described observations.
The procedural actions described were correctly performed and recorded.
defeaters: If evidence showed confirmed mechanical faults or repeated malfunctions, or if procedural deviations were documented that could explain the event, the conclusion might change.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active human control and procedural actions during pushback, with no indication of mechanical failure, favoring mechanical/control failure as the plausible cause over procedural deviation (disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE).
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit mechanical fault confirmation; reliance on procedural and observational evidence

assumptions: No mechanical fault codes or bench test results are present in the evidence
Procedural and communication details are accurate and complete
defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found
If physical evidence of hardware faults or bench checks confirmed control malfunction
If communication failures without hardware faults were ruled out
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe human actions, communication, and procedural context without any indication of mechanical or control failure; the continued movement beyond the TRP suggests procedural or operator error rather than mechanical fault, thus contradicting the claim that mechanical/control failure aligns with key features.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity in cause of continued movement beyond TRP
